choices.text: Necrosis (A), Apoptosis(B), normal pattern (C)
Necrosis (B), Apoptosis(C), normal pattern (A)
Necrosis (C), Apoptosis(B), normal pattern (A)
Necrosis (B), Apoptosis(A), normal pattern (C)

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched option about the pattern of cell death and the DNA electrophoresis pattern shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrosis (C), Apoptosis(B), normal pattern (A)

 

Option C:

 

Explanation:

The image shown is an agarose gel used for DNA electrophoresis, displaying three distinct patterns which correlate with different cellular states:

 

  • Lane A shows a normal DNA pattern used as a reference.
  • Lane B displays a ladder pattern, characteristic of DNA fragmentation occurring during apoptosis, where the DNA is cleaved at internucleosomal regions.
  • Lane C shows a smear pattern, which is typical for necrosis, where DNA is randomly degraded.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DNA electrophoresis, a step ladder pattern is indicative of apoptosis due to regular internucleosomal DNA cleavage, whereas a smear pattern is associated with the random DNA degradation seen in necrosis.

choices.text: Genes which inhibit apoptosis: bcl-XS
Pro apoptosis genes: MCL-1
BH3 genes:  BCL-XL
Gene acting as apoptosis initiators: BAD

questions.text: Which of the following is the true statement about the genes regulating apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gene acting as apoptosis initiators: BAD

 

Option D:

BAD is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, known as a BH3-only protein, which initiates apoptosis by antagonizing the function of Bcl-2 and similar proteins. about the genes regulating apoptosis:

 

Explanation:

Option A. Bcl-XS is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, not an inhibitor of apoptosis

 

Option B. MCL-1 has a complex role in apoptosis. It has both pro- and anti-apoptotic isoforms. However, MCL-1 is generally considered to be anti-apoptotic.

 

Option C. BCL-XL is an anti-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, not a BH3-only protein. BH3-only proteins are pro-apoptotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAD is a pro-apoptotic gene that acts as an initiator of apoptosis. It is part of the BH3-only subgroup of the Bcl-2 family, which promotes apoptosis by neutralizing the function of anti-apoptotic proteins within the cell.Top of FormBottom of Form

choices.text: Free radical injury in utero
Necroptosis
Ferroptosis
Apoptosis

questions.text: As a baby develops in utero, fingers and toes are attached together in the form of webs. Around 10 weeks of gestation, fingers and toes separate, elongate and lose their webbing. Which of the following physiological processes aids this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Apoptosis

 

Option D:

The removal of supernumerary cells (in excess of the required number) during development including webs is aided by physiological apoptosis.

Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death crucial for the normal development and removal of cells no longer needed, such as the cells in the webbing between fingers and toes during fetal development.

Explanation:

 

Option A. Free radical injury is typically harmful and not a normal part of physiological development.

 

Option B. This is a form of programmed cell death, but it is not responsible for the normal differentiation and development processes that occur in utero.

 

Option C. Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent form of non-apoptotic cell death, not involved in the typical development of fingers and toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptosis plays a key role in embryonic development, including the separation and elongation of fingers and toes, by removing excess cells to shape the developing tissues correctly.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed (Latest)- Pg: 42

choices.text: Apaf 1
Bcl-2
FADD
TNF

questions.text: Apoptosome is formed by the binding of cytochrome C with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apaf 1

 

Option A:

Cytochrome c binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming a multimeric structure called the apoptosome. This complex binds to caspase-9, the critical initiator caspase of the mitochondrial pathway, and promotes its autocatalytic cleavage, generating catalytically active forms of the enzyme. Formation of the apoptosome is an important step in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. BCL-2 has anti-apoptotic activity.

Option C. FADD is a key component of the death receptor or extrinsic pathway. This extrinsic apoptosis pathway can be inhibited by a protein called FLIP, which binds to pro- caspase - 8, thereby blocking FADD binding, but cannot activate the caspase.

 

Option D. Death receptors in the death receptor pathway or extrinsic pathway are type 1 TNF receptor (TNFR1) pathway and a related protein called Fas (CD95).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The apoptosome is formed by the binding of cytochrome C with Apaf-1, initiating the activation of caspase-9, which is a key event in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /45

choices.text: Marker of hairy cell leukemia
Not associated with caspase dependent programmed cell death
Marker of necrosis
Antibodies directed against annexin V are seen in antiphospholipid syndrome

questions.text: What is the role of annexin V in cellular processes, and how is it associated with pathological conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibodies directed against annexin V are seen in antiphospholipid syndrome

 

Option D:

 

In antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), antibodies against annexin V are seen. Annexin V normally forms a protective shield around phospholipid molecules, inhibiting coagulation; when this shield is disrupted in APS, it can result in a thrombophilic state.

 

  • Annexin V is a marker of apoptosis (caspase dependent programmed cell death) whereas annexin A1 is for hairy cell leukemia.
  • Antibodies directed against annexin V are seen with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). 
  • Annexin V normally forms a shield around certain phospholipid molecules that blocks their entry into coagulation (clotting) reactions. In APS, the antibodies disrupt the shield.  And an increased quantity of phospholipid molecules on cell membranes speeding up coagulation reactions typically thrombophilic property in antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Annexin A1, not annexin V, is associated with hairy cell leukemia.

Option B. Annexin V is a marker of apoptosis, which is a caspase-dependent programmed cell death process.

 

Option C. Annexin V is not a marker of necrosis; instead, it binds to phosphatidylserine on the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, which is a hallmark of apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Annexin V is associated with apoptosis, where it binds to phosphatidylserine on the surface of apoptotic cells. Antibodies against annexin V are characteristic of antiphospholipid syndrome, where they can interfere with annexin V's normal anticoagulant function, contributing to a pro-thrombotic state.

choices.text: Pinocytosis
Entosis
Efferocytosis
Exocytosis

questions.text: A developing embryo undergoes physiological apoptosis. Which of the following processes contribute to the absence of inflammation during apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Efferocytosis

 

Option C:

 

 

Efferocytosis is the process where phagocytes engulf and remove apoptotic cells, thereby preventing the release of inflammatory contents from dying cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pinocytosis is a form of endocytosis that cells use to ingest extracellular fluid and small particles, not specifically for clearing apoptotic cells.

 

Option B. Entosis is a process where one cell is engulfed by another cell, but it's not related to the clearance of apoptotic cells to prevent inflammation.

 

Option D. Exocytosis is the process of vesicles fusing with the plasma membrane to release their contents outside the cell, not related to the engulfment and clearance of apoptotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efferocytosis is the engulfment of apoptotic cells by phagocytes. This process is highly efficient and quick, leading to the rapid removal of dying cells without triggering inflammation, a crucial mechanism during embryonic development to maintain tissue homeostasis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 46

choices.text: Cytochrome P450
p53
β-Catenin
E-Cadherin

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with Hodgkin lymphoma undergoes 3 sessions of radiotherapy. Microscopic examination in the field of radiation reveals numerous acidophilic bodies and small cells with pyknotic nuclei. Which of the following proteins most likely played a key role in triggering radiation-induced cell death in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) p53

 

Option B:

Apoptosis detects and destroys cells that harbor dangerous mutations, thereby maintaining genetic consistency and preventing the development of cancer.

  • p53 is the responder by which the cell recognizes genomic abnormalities and “assesses” whether they can be repaired.
  • If the damage to DNA is so severe that it cannot be repaired, the cascade of events leading to apoptosis is activated, and the cell dies.
  • p53 activates proteins that arrest the cell in G1 of the cell cycle, allowing time for DNA repair to proceed. It repair is successful, the cell survives and if DNA damage cannot be repaired, p53 activates mechanisms that terminate in apoptosis.

 

p53 is known as the "guardian of the genome" and plays a critical role in triggering cell death in response to irreparable DNA damage, such as that caused by radiotherapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cytochrome P450 enzymes are involved in drug metabolism and are not directly associated with the cellular response to DNA damage.

 

Option C. β-Catenin is involved in cell signaling and adhesion, with roles in the Wnt signaling pathway and not directly in DNA damage response.

 

Option D. E-Cadherin is a cell adhesion molecule important for maintaining cell-to-cell junctions and is not involved in the DNA damage response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following DNA damage from radiotherapy, p53 assesses the severity of genomic abnormalities and determines whether to activate repair mechanisms or proceed to apoptosis if the damage is beyond repair.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/45
